_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE STATIONARY SOURCE
The Tropicale Foods, LLC, (Tropicale) Facility (Facility) in Lubbock, Texas produces and stores ice cream products. Anhydrous ammonia, an acutely hazardous material (AHM), is used in the Facility refrigeration system, which has an estimated inventory of approximately 29,046 pounds. This inventory exceeds the 40 CFR Part 68 Risk Management Program (RMP) and federal OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) 29 CFR 1910.119 10,000-pound threshold quantity. The Facility has developed a Risk Management Plan following federal EPA requirements. Tropicale acquired the Dynamic Foods facility in August 2022 and updated the facility and ammonia refrigeration system. Tropicale is committed to worker and public safety through investing in accident prevention programs, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system. Tropicale relies on support services provided by the local fire department in the unlikely event that a chemical release does occur at the Facility.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED 
The Tropicale Facility is located at 1001 East 33rd Street, Lubbock, Texas, (APN R113676) and south of two rail transfer areas. The Facility is approximately 1.2 miles east of US Highway 27 and 0.9 miles south of State Highway 62. The Facility is located in an industrial area with residences approximately 260 yards to the south. The Facility has one anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system. 

The ammonia refrigeration system is a two-stage system. The high stage compressors have a 28-psig suction pressure (+15° F) and a normal discharge pressure of approximately 150-180 psig. Booster compressors operate at 14.3 Hg suction pressure (-50° F) and a discharge pressure of approximately 28 psig. The refrigeration system is composed of the following key components:
?	2  Condensers, BAC model VRC-1434A-2418N-NA
?

1  Control pressure receiver, 54 x 192
?	1  Thermosiphon receiver, 30 x 91 OAL
?	2  Vilter dual high stage screw compressors, model VSS-751 (existing)
?	1  GEA high stage screw compressor, model 475 GLX (new)
?	2  GEA booster screw compressors, model 1435GLX (new)
?	  Compressors have thermosiphon oil cooling heat exchangers
?	6  Superior ice cream freezers, model DF-1500 (new)
?	22  Air handler evaporators, hot gas defrost (existing)
?	3  Colmac Air handler evaporators, hot gas defrost (new)
?	1  Colmac air handler evaporator for the engine room, air defrost (new)
?	1  Evapco MAU air handler for process room cooling (new) 
?	1  Surge drum for MAU-1 Make-up air unit, 20 x 72 OAL
?	1  Low temp recirculator, 84 x 167H (245 OAH)
?	1  Oil pot for LTR, 10.75 x 36 OAL
?	1  High temp recirculator/Intercooler, 84 x 167H (245 OAH)
?	1  Oil pot for HTR/IC, 10.75 x 36 OAL
?	3  Process line heat exchangers with surge drums, 36 x 96 OAL
?	4  Ammonia pumps (2-high and 2 low temp), Nikkiso Model HQ23C-B1
?	2  Brine (CaCl2) loop pumps, Armstrong 4030 6 x 5 x 13H
?	3  Brine (CaCl2) transfer pumps, Armstrong 4030 3 x 1.5 x 10
?	Emergency pressure control system (EPCS)
?	Ammonia detection and alarm system 

The operating cycle begins with condensed liquid from the condenser units draining into the thermosiphon (TS) and control pressure receiver (CPR) vessels. The TS vessel supplies liquid ammonia to the compressor oil coolers. High pressure liquid is fed by pressure differential to the high temperature recirculator (HTR) and the engine room air unit (AU1). The pressure in the CPR is maintained by the high temperature recirculated suction. Liquid ammonia is pumped from the HTR to high temperature units; MAU-1 and surge drum, ice cream freezers 1-6, and evaporators in the thaw rooms, blend room, 40-degree process room and dock. Vapors from the top of the HTR are drawn into the high stage compressors where it is compressed, and the pressure is incre

ased. The superheated compressor discharge travels through the evaporative condensers where the ammonia gas gives up its heat and condenses to a liquid and returned to the high-pressure receiver to begin the cycle once again.

Booster compressors draw dry low temperature vapors (LTS) from the top of the low temperature recirculator (LTR) and discharge compressed vapor to the HTR where it provides pressure to the HTR vessel. Liquid makeup to the LTR is medium pressure liquid (MPL) from the HTR. LTR vessel level is controlled through level sensors and liquid solenoids. Low temperature recirculated liquid (LTRL) ammonia is pumped from the LTR to freezer units (-40° F) surge drums (SD-1 & SD-2) and two brine and one glycol heat exchanger liquid/suction in the Stick Room (popsicles) and to ice cream freezers 1-6 (IC1-IC6). LTRS wet (vapor/liquid) is drawn into the LTR by booster suction pressure. The LTR provides liquid/vapor phase separation of the incoming wet suction. The LTRS is drawn from low temperature surge drums and heat exchangers 1 and 2, ice cream freezer low temperature evaporators 1-6, and -40° F freezers. 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL -SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Tropicale has implemented prevention program elements to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia for refrigeration. The RMP/PSM Prevention Program elements include the following:
?	Process Safety Information
?	Process Hazard Analysis
?	Operating Procedures
?	Training Programs
?	Mechanical Integrity
?	Management of Change
?	Pre-startup Safety Review
?	Compliance Audits
?	Incident Investigation
?	Employee Participation
?	Hot Work 
?	Contractor Safety
?	Trade Secrets (if applicable)

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no releases that resulted in onsite or offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
Tropicale will not respond to uncontrolled release

s of ammonia from the process and will rely on support services provided by the local fire department in the unlikely event that a chemical release occurs. Tropicale has written and implemented an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the Facility. The EAP describes initial actions to evacuate the Facility to designated assembly areas and wait for instructions from outside emergency response agencies. The EAP is periodically reviewed by Tropicale management and is coordinated annually with emergency response agencies.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Tropicale performed a process hazard analysis (PHA) in June 2023. The PHA team prepared a list of recommendations or action items to eliminate and/or mitigate the scenarios if the level of protection appeared insufficient. PHA recommendations are found in the 2023 Initial PHA Recommendation Resolution Tracking document. PHA team recommendations included:
	Verify that access to the recirculator vessel area is restricted to authorized personnel.
	Implement the established Mechanical Integrity program.
	Verify the machinery room doors are tight fitting, self-closing, open outward, have panic-style hardware, and are 1-hour fire rated. 
	Verify the ammonia detection system alarms to a constantly monitored location when alarming, on loss of power, or on loss of signal.
	Provide access to the machinery room to qualified operators only.

Tropicale recognizes that the RMP/PSM Program is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring, and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operations at its Facility. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as Tropicale continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their employees and surrounding community. Tropicale will submit revised information if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements/modifications to the RMP/PSM Progra

ms, related attachments, and program elements will be incorporated consistent with Tropicales internal review practices, and Tropicale will maintain the most current versions onsite. Thus, the most current version of the RMP/PSM Programs and related documents and elements maintained onsite may vary slightly from the information in submittals made to regulatory agencies.
